paragraphs.text: 'Selma' sets off new fight over Martin Luther King's contested legacy.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Dr  Martin Luther King Jr  died young -- at age 39 -- and ever since his assassination in 1968 there has been a contest over his legacy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I've met black radicals who sneer at the national holiday celebrating his birth
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: They see the King holiday as white America's preference for celebrating a moderate, non-violent black leader instead of a militant, violent young Malcolm X.
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On the other side are critics who see the King holiday as political correctness taken to new heights
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: King was not a president, like Washington and Lincoln
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: so
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they ask why he is deserving of a national holiday
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Blinded by racial bitterness, they suggest President Reagan signed the King holiday into law in 1983 as a token political gesture
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Now a very good, emotionally powerful new movie -- "Selma" -- about Dr  King's historic role in the struggle for voting rights has set off a new fight over his legacy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This dramatic film by director, Ava DuVernay, will be remembered less as a record of Dr  King's greatness and more as a sign of the racial power struggles of the early 21st century
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I know the real civil rights story
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I've written two best-selling histories of the period
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The greatest social movement of the last century belongs to all Americans
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But some people prefer to play racial games
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This movie fits in with the racially divisive discussion about who owns the history of the civil rights movement
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It fits with polarizing racial figures like Jesse Jackson and Al Sharpton
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They regularly exploit the history of the civil rights movement for their own personal gain
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: hosting television shows and getting money from corporations
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: while not doing the hard work of addressing high rates of black crime, school dropouts and family breakdown
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is also fits with many white politicians
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: who blame the poor for every problem and find it easy to push minority voters out of their districts while ignoring the nation's history of denying black people the right to vote
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Now a version of the same race hustle is on display in Hollywood
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: To celebrate King as a hero, the director, who is black decided to make President Lyndon Johnson into a white villain
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In one scene Johnson erupts in anger at Dr  King, telling the civil rights leader,"You've got one big issue, I've got one hundred and one."
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: People who were in the room, black and white aides to the president and Dr  King, say no such confrontation ever happened
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The movie also has Johnson approving of FBI Director J  Edgar Hoover's scheme to send Dr  King's wife an audio recording of her husband having sex with another woman
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The historical record is clear
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yes, the tape is real
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: No, Johnson had nothing to do it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And the tape had nothing to do with events in Selma
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: All of that is what Bill Moyers called"the worst kind of creative license suggesting the very opposite of the truth."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the director, DuVernay, was called on the distortion, she said people who care about history are the problem
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: She argued that crediting Johnson with supporting the Selma march was "jaw-dropping and offensive" and amounted to ignoring "black citizens who made it so."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: To her, the fact that Johnson explicitly endorsed the idea of taking the movement to Selma in a recorded phone call to Dr  King is just a nuisance
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: White directors have similarly distorted civil rights history
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The 1988 film "Mississippi Burning" featured two heroes, both white and both FBI agents
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: That was an incredible distortion of a story about the bravery of civil rights workers who dared to go south to stand with beleaguered black heroes against racial oppression
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In truth, the FBI was often in league with local police departments in covering up racially motivated murder
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In 1988 that distortion was rationalized as a smart box office decision to offer white heroes to white audiences
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Now that a black director has a chance to make Hollywood's first big movie about Dr  King, she sees it as time for payback and her own brand of distortion
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Race retains a powerful grip on American guilt, fear, lust and anger
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That's why controlling the narrative is so important
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And the key to the narrative is in the facts of slavery, legal segregation and the fight for equal rights
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That is why facts about Dr  King are subject to a constant power struggle
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.label: anecdote
